boardgame.name: Alea Iacta Est
boardgame.description: Alea Iacta Est is Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot;The Die is Cast_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot;._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Players take on the role of Caesar and compete for the most prestige points. This happens by clever placement of his/her eight dice, which are placed on five different buildings._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;At the Castrum (barracks), new provinces can be conquered, while patricians can be recruited at the Forum Romanum to be sent to those provinces. At the Senatus, cards can be won for bonuses that will be kept secret until the end of the game. The Templum awards prestige points directly from the Goddess Fortuna. Each die that does not win any of these ends the round at the Latrina, where it provides its owner with a _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ldquo;repete!_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rdquo; chip, which can be used to re-roll dice or can be traded in two-to-one for prestige points at the end of the game. Each building has special rules as to how the dice can be placed, allowing many tactical possibilities with any roll of the dice._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Each round ends when one player has placed his/her last die, and after 5 rounds (6 rounds with 2-3 players), the patricians are organized in their provinces, the senate cards are revealed, and the scores are totaled. The player with the most prestige points wins!_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

I ship everything via USPS Priority Mail flat rate boxes - with _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;Fragile,_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;Keep Dry,_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; and _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;Do Not Bend_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; written on the boxes. The rate structure for those boxes is as follows: Shipping for games that will fit within a 8.5_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; X 5.25_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; X 1.5_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; box costs $4.95. Shipping for games that will fit within a 13.5_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; X 11.75_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; X 3.25_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; box costs $10.70. I can easily combine shipping if games will fit within these boxes. If they don_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;t, I can still combine shipping, but that is a little tricker. Thursdays are the days I get most of my shipping done, if that helps you.
reserved for Matt Buckingham. Please send payment to larryjrice@juno.com and I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll let the contributing member know to ship the game!

Rio Grande Games (RIO 395) Type: Set collecting Number of players: 2-5 Age of players: 9++ Length: 60 minutes Game Description: Each player tries to be Caesar and then works to prove he is indeed Caesar by collecting fame points. The challenge is to intelligently allocate your eight rolled dice among the five buildings to acquire the fame you need to win the game. Clever Caesar would use these resources to conquer new provinces and assign suitable patricians to them, adding to his already enormous fame. Can you do the same? You will also need to show diplomacy in the senate and maybe visit the temple for some luck from Fortuna to win. Although dice-rolling is luck-based, the options offered here go well beyond luck. You cannot control (well, sometimes you can, actually) the dice you get, but clever allocation of _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;bad_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; dice rolls can yield good results. When the dice allocation is done, the buildings are scored and another set begins. At game end, the player with the most fame points.

Game is in excellent condition. All the components are present and correct. Rio Grande english version.
Weight inc packing 830g UK First class £4.25 Surface Worldwide £6.50 Europe Airmail £6.41 USA Airmail £11.42
Shipping costs shown are for an individual game. I will combine shipping as best I can. Large packages (5kg, say 6 games) are very cost-effective to ship internationally via DHL. Ask if you want a detailed price.
sealed. will ship quickly. Canadian purchasers please email me about postage before you purchase.

Rio Grande Games (RIO395) Each player tries to be Caesar and then works to prove he is indeed Caesar by collecting fame points. The challenge is to intelligently allocate your eight rolled dice among the five buildings to acquire the fame you need to win the game. Clever Caesar would use these resources to conquer new provinces and assign suitable patricians to them, adding to his already enormous fame. Can you do the same? You will also need to show diplomacy in the senate and maybe visit the temple for some luck from Fortuna to win. Although dice-rolling is luck-based, the options offered here go well beyond luck. You cannot control (well, sometimes you can, actually) the dice you get, but clever allocation of _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;bad_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; dice rolls can yield good results. When the dice allocation is done, the buildings are scored and another set begins. At game end, the player with the most fame points.

You cannot control (well, sometimes you can, actually) the dice you get, but clever allocation of _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;bad_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; dice rolls can yield good results. When the dice allocation is done, the buildings are scored and another set begins. At game end, the player with the most fame points.

Rio Grande Games (RIO395) Each player tries to be Caesar and then works to prove he is indeed Caesar by collecting fame points. The challenge is to intelligently allocate your eight rolled dice among the five buildings to acquire the fame you need to win the game. Clever Caesar would use these resources to conquer new provinces and assign suitable patricians to them, adding to his already enormous fame. Can you do the same? You will also need to show diplomacy in the senate and maybe visit the temple for some luck from Fortuna to win. Although dice-rolling is luck-based, the options offered here go well beyond luck. You cannot control (well, sometimes you can, actually) the dice you get, but clever allocation of _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;bad_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; dice rolls can yield good results. When the dice allocation is done, the buildings are scored and another set begins. At game end, the player with the most fame points.

*Shipping via USPS medium flat rate at $13.65, unless price is cheaper due to proximity of delivery. Alea Iacta Est is Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;The Die is Cast_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;. Players take on the role of Caesar and compete for the most prestige points. This happens by clever placement of his/her eight dice, which are placed on five different buildings. At the Castrum (barracks), new provinces can be conquered, while patricians can be recruited at the Forum Romanum to be sent to those provinces. At the Senatus, cards can be won for bonuses that will be kept secret until the end of the game. The Templum awards prestige points directly from the Goddess Fortuna. Each die that does not win any of these ends the round at the Latrina, where it provides its owner with a “repete!” chip, which can be used to re-roll dice or can be traded in two-to-one for prestige points at the end of the game. Each building has special rules as to how the dice can be placed, allowing many tactical possibilities with any roll of the dice. Each round ends when one player has placed his/her last die, and after 5 rounds (6 rounds with 2-3 players), the patricians are organized in their provinces, the senate cards are revealed, and the scores are totaled. The player with the most prestige points wins!
Very good condition- played a few times.
